text: Stars Reach has another play test this past week, on Wednesday evening Pacific time, as a follow on to the previous tools and terrain modification test a couple of weeks back.  So we were once again let loose on a patch of terrain. Once again let loose on pristine terrain This test was in part to see if changes made to combat the lag we were seeing would have an effect as well as to throw two new tools into the mix. The first was the chronophaser, which would erode or lithify materials. Chronophase this This tool didn’t do much for me, though admittedly I tried it mid-test when we had the maximum number of people on and were seeing some odd behavior… not so much lag as problems responding to and displaying what one was doing.  Erosion might just be a slow process. Also, I suspect somebody might need to workshop some words.  Lithify sounds like the technically correct word, yet isn’t a term that yields an “oh, I know what that means/does” in many people. More interesting was the block tool.  This lets you play Minecraft in Stars Reach, for lack of a better analogy. Block tool For purposes of the test the block tool needed slate, a specific material that you had to find and mine with the extractor tool.  I found some exposed on a hill side and went to work mining that. Collecting shale to build with That collected, I started playing with blocks.  While you can deploy selections of blocks as walls and floors, I started off just playing with them one at a time to see how things latched and responded. Putting a block up It seemed to work about as expected.  The blocks were available in different textures, though I stuck with the default brick.  As you can see, things were floating a bit above the terrain and there was some delay in the time between when you clicked to place a block and when it appeared.  There was some minor lag by that time, so it could be related to that. After putting together some blocks I decided to see how some of the other tools would affect them.  As it turns out, they don’t.  The blocks were non-destructible for the purposes of this test, so when I applied the agitator to them set to heat, nothing happened to the blocks. The heat, however, did pass though to the ground below the blocks, forming a pool of lava below my meager platform. Maybe it could be a lava moat? The blocks were also not proof against the lava.  I jumped up on the platform and caught fire, so had to retreat. Other people were more inventive.  I mean, sure, some of us were just out there melting stuff again, because when you have an agitator you want to melt all the things. Mountain melting in progress There were a couple of attempts to undermine features of the terrain, including a rock hillock that I initially tunneled through which then become somebody’s pet project to completely dig beneath. Digging under the hill The terrain model wasn’t quite up to the task of dropping that chunk onto the ground below it, though people underneath died at various points, no doubt due to the calculation that they were in a currently untenable position. Somebody had used the floor mode from the block tool to extend a long sky road… for lack of a better term… over the hill and then began trying to melt it from above. Now melting… this hill I went up and around to get on the platform they were working from and quickly found that the heat from below was enough to set people on fire again. Melting from above One person was hitting people with the cold setting of the agitator to chill them out.  It is hard to see, but I am wreathed in flame there. Then there was the pillar of ice rising up from the largest body of water. Me flying around keeping an eye on the ice You use the agitator to boil the water and water vapor as steam rises up into the sky, higher and higher.  Things get colder as they go up in altitude and eventually the steam becomes water again which becomes ice and then the ice crept down the pillar, with the help of agitators set to cold, until there was a pillar of ice in the middle of the landscape. It made a nice landmark as there is no map yet in the game and somehow I can get lost in a very small area.  However, like the flag pole on a freezing day, don’t touch the ice pillar, it is death. Other people drained off various pools of water for one experiment or another. Only you can prevent this sort of thing Still others spent time building things.  There were a number of houses around the terrain.  There was also the Stars Reach logo done up with the block tool. It helps when your logo is already a bit blocky Somebody else spelled out STARS REACH on the top of a slope, though had to dig out some terrain to get it to show. Stars Reach is here You can see a lot of stuff going on in this panorama of the fields after we had been at it for most of the two hour play test. A look out over all we did There are structures and holes and melted landscape and landscape still molten and the ice spire and more going on there. Eventually though time ran down and the devs closed out by summoning some monsters for us to spar with before the server was shut down.  Raph wasn’t on to accidentally cause a huge mass of mobs to be summoned, as happened last time, but there was more variety this time, including some immense flying mobs. A giant beast attacking the spawn point I ran around trying to get closer.  Somebody had built flooring all around the spawn and then had tried to melt it as I had earlier, only to turn the ground below the floor into lava.  You can see me wreathed in flames much more clearly in this shot. Fighting while on fire Then things were shut down.  Another play test complete. This one ran more smoothly than the previous one, with the lag monster, if not fully tamed, at least not rearing its ugly head with quite the reckless abandon it had before. I think the tools we were issued were toned down a bit from the previous round.  I was not able to dig nearly as handily with the excavator as I did last time around.  I mean, determined to tunnel I could tunnel, but I was practically a mole at times during the last test while this time around I found the digging not going nearly as quickly nor as smoothly. As noted previously, this is not anything like a look at what the vision is for the completed game, but just a taste of a small aspect of what might come to be.  There is a lot that needs to be wrapped around this and during the test we were told a bit more about skills and career tracks (along with dev blog about it) and the fact that you can learn all the things but cannot have all your learning active and equipped… or something like that.
html:
Stars Reach has another play test this past week, on Wednesday evening Pacific time, as a follow on to the previous tools and terrain modification test a couple of weeks back.  So we were once again let loose on a patch of terrain.

Once again let loose on pristine terrain

This test was in part to see if changes made to combat the lag we were seeing would have an effect as well as to throw two new tools into the mix.

The first was the chronophaser, which would erode or lithify materials.

Chronophase this

This tool didn’t do much for me, though admittedly I tried it mid-test when we had the maximum number of people on and were seeing some odd behavior… not so much lag as problems responding to and displaying what one was doing.  Erosion might just be a slow process.

Also, I suspect somebody might need to workshop some words.  Lithify sounds like the technically correct word, yet isn’t a term that yields an “oh, I know what that means/does” in many people.

More interesting was the block tool.  This lets you play Minecraft in Stars Reach, for lack of a better analogy.

Block tool

For purposes of the test the block tool needed slate, a specific material that you had to find and mine with the extractor tool.  I found some exposed on a hill side and went to work mining that.

Collecting shale to build with

That collected, I started playing with blocks.  While you can deploy selections of blocks as walls and floors, I started off just playing with them one at a time to see how things latched and responded.

Putting a block up

It seemed to work about as expected.  The blocks were available in different textures, though I stuck with the default brick.  As you can see, things were floating a bit above the terrain and there was some delay in the time between when you clicked to place a block and when it appeared.  There was some minor lag by that time, so it could be related to that.

After putting together some blocks I decided to see how some of the other tools would affect them.  As it turns out, they don’t.  The blocks were non-destructible for the purposes of this test, so when I applied the agitator to them set to heat, nothing happened to the blocks.

The heat, however, did pass though to the ground below the blocks, forming a pool of lava below my meager platform.

Maybe it could be a lava moat?

The blocks were also not proof against the lava.  I jumped up on the platform and caught fire, so had to retreat.

Other people were more inventive.  I mean, sure, some of us were just out there melting stuff again, because when you have an agitator you want to melt all the things.

Mountain melting in progress

There were a couple of attempts to undermine features of the terrain, including a rock hillock that I initially tunneled through which then become somebody’s pet project to completely dig beneath.

Digging under the hill

The terrain model wasn’t quite up to the task of dropping that chunk onto the ground below it, though people underneath died at various points, no doubt due to the calculation that they were in a currently untenable position.

Somebody had used the floor mode from the block tool to extend a long sky road… for lack of a better term… over the hill and then began trying to melt it from above.

Now melting… this hill

I went up and around to get on the platform they were working from and quickly found that the heat from below was enough to set people on fire again.

Melting from above

One person was hitting people with the cold setting of the agitator to chill them out.  It is hard to see, but I am wreathed in flame there.

Then there was the pillar of ice rising up from the largest body of water.

Me flying around keeping an eye on the ice

You use the agitator to boil the water and water vapor as steam rises up into the sky, higher and higher.  Things get colder as they go up in altitude and eventually the steam becomes water again which becomes ice and then the ice crept down the pillar, with the help of agitators set to cold, until there was a pillar of ice in the middle of the landscape.

It made a nice landmark as there is no map yet in the game and somehow I can get lost in a very small area.  However, like the flag pole on a freezing day, don’t touch the ice pillar, it is death.

Other people drained off various pools of water for one experiment or another.

Only you can prevent this sort of thing

Still others spent time building things.  There were a number of houses around the terrain.  There was also the Stars Reach logo done up with the block tool.

It helps when your logo is already a bit blocky

Somebody else spelled out STARS REACH on the top of a slope, though had to dig out some terrain to get it to show.

Stars Reach is here

You can see a lot of stuff going on in this panorama of the fields after we had been at it for most of the two hour play test.

A look out over all we did

There are structures and holes and melted landscape and landscape still molten and the ice spire and more going on there.

Eventually though time ran down and the devs closed out by summoning some monsters for us to spar with before the server was shut down.  Raph wasn’t on to accidentally cause a huge mass of mobs to be summoned, as happened last time, but there was more variety this time, including some immense flying mobs.

A giant beast attacking the spawn point

I ran around trying to get closer.  Somebody had built flooring all around the spawn and then had tried to melt it as I had earlier, only to turn the ground below the floor into lava.  You can see me wreathed in flames much more clearly in this shot.

Fighting while on fire

Then things were shut down.  Another play test complete.

This one ran more smoothly than the previous one, with the lag monster, if not fully tamed, at least not rearing its ugly head with quite the reckless abandon it had before.

I think the tools we were issued were toned down a bit from the previous round.  I was not able to dig nearly as handily with the excavator as I did last time around.  I mean, determined to tunnel I could tunnel, but I was practically a mole at times during the last test while this time around I found the digging not going nearly as quickly nor as smoothly.

As noted previously, this is not anything like a look at what the vision is for the completed game, but just a taste of a small aspect of what might come to be.  There is a lot that needs to be wrapped around this and during the test we were told a bit more about skills and career tracks (along with dev blog about it) and the fact that you can learn all the things but cannot have all your learning active and equipped… or something like that.
